title: Strictly's Motsi Mabuse 'thankful' for dance after 'hard childhood'
text:
Strictly Come Dancing’s Motsi Mabuse ‘thankful’ for dance (Picture: Getty Images)

Strictly Come Dancing’s Motsi Mabuse has opened up about her childhood and how she was thankful for dance.

The star was made a judge on Strictly for the first time this year, meaning she gets to critique her little sister Oti – who is partnered up with soapie Kelvin Fletcher.

But it turns out their lifestyle wasn’t always glitz and glam, as the 38-year-old expressed when chatting to The Mirror.

In a candid interview, she told the publication: ‘I’m so thankful for dance because if I had grown up with just the bitterness of the very hard childhood we had, and I’d never ­experienced the love of the dance world, then I probably would have been a very sad person.

‘Finding people to give us the instructions was difficult. It was a very difficult time in South Africa, so to be a little girl and push yourself in this type of dancing, where there are no other black girls, was really tough.’

She said she had a difficult childhood (Picture: Getty Images)

She added: ‘And when we did get the chance to learn the waltz and the cha cha cha, at a weekend club, we were soon better than the teacher.’

But the duo have managed to come through their darker days and can now be found spinning around the ballroom on the BBC show.

Just last week, Motsi was left in tears following Paralympian Will Bayley and his pro partner Janette Manrara’s routine.

However, it looks as though they won’t need the tissues tonight, as the star pulled out of this week after medical advice.

Claudia Winkleman made the announcement at the beginning of the live show, revealing that he had injured himself in rehearsals.

The dancer cried over Will’s performance last week (Picture: PA)

The 31-year-old table tennis player who won gold at the Rio 2016 Paralympics, was born with arthrogryposis – a condition which causes curved joints affecting all four of his limbs.

He was later diagnosed with non-Hodgkin lymphoma, a rare form of cancer, aged seven, and was treated at Great Ormond Street Children’s hospital who helped him through rehabilitation.

Taking to Twitter ahead of the show, he wrote: ‘Hi everyone, I am absolutely gutted I cannot be performing tonight on strictly with Janette, sadly I’m injured and not fit to dance.

‘I hope to be back on the dance floor next week. Good luck to everyone tonight. Thanks for all your messages guys, I’ll be back!!’

Janette later told Claudia: ‘Things happen and we will move forward and be back.’

Strictly Come Dancing continues Sunday night on BBC One.
